captions.text:
(music)
I love science

Can you even imagine
Way back in the past when

We thought that storms were caused by petty
gods
Fightin' on top of a mountain?

And yeah I like a good story
But eventually it's gonna bore me

If it doesn't have that truth;
That incontrovertible, testable, repeatable
proof

I love science
And I love Charles Darwin

Cause I don't think it's bold to question
what you're told

If you're told that the world's a thousand
years old.

There's nothing here to argue against;
It's a process, not an ideology,
And I! Love! Science!
And I! Love! Science!

Sometimes people ask me,
Of all of the centuries,

Which I'd pick to live life in.
We'll, that's pretty easy

Right now. If you think objectively.
If you like hot running water,

And memory foam beds,
And TV shows and cell phones,
And not being dead

Then you love science,
And I love Carl Sagan

'Cause I think it's fly to look up at the
sky

And never, ever, ever stop wondering why
There's nothing here to argue against

It's a process, not an ideology,
I! Love! Science!

Wooly mammoth embryos
Vaccines for smallpox and polio

Your TV set, the internet
Your PS4, supersonic jets.

Exoplanets, galaxies,
DNA, germ theory, relativity,

Just take a sec to think about it
How sad life would be without it.
(sweet drum solo)

I love science
And I love Rosalind Franklin,

'Cause I want to die remembering why
The truth is more important than winning a

prize.
There's nothing here to argue against.

It's a process, not an ideology,
And I! Love! Science!

That is the first track on my new album Incongruent
with Hank Green and The Perfect Strangers.

Incongruent now has an official release date,
that date being May 7th. That's when it

will be available on iTunes. It will be shipping
out of the DFTBA warehouse a little bit before

that. All of those things shipping out, if
you pre-order the album, will be signed, and

you will also get an email with download links
so that you can download the MP3s 'cause

I know not everybody has a CD drive in their
computer anymore.

And we are going on tour after VidCon! Los
Angeles, San Francisco, Portland, Seattle,

Boise, Denver, Salt Lake City, possibly Eugene,
there's a link in the description if you

want to get tickets. For some peculiar reasons
it is extra important that we sell tickets

in Seattle, Salt Lake and Denver quickly.
Basically, the people booking the shows don't

believe us 'cause we've nerve toured before
and we need to show them that we can sell

tickets so they will be nice to us. And it
is not just me on this tour: it is also Rob

Scallon, it is also Andrew Huang, it is also
Driftless Pony Club, the band of Wheezy Waiter,

and it is also Harry and the Potters! It's
going to be a lot of fun! I'm excited about

it! All the shows are all ages, and all the
tickets are under $20, the prices vary. I
love science! John, I'll see you on Tuesday.

title: I Love Science (Clean Version) (Uncensored link in the Description)

comments.text:
Science may not be an ideology, but scientism, a philosophical ideology 
that many men of science subscribe to is one. It is the belief that all 
reality must be described by and reducible to physical properties and 
processes, which is a claim that, by nature cannot be proven definitely 
through empirical means.﻿

comments.author: Dani Gorddard

comments.text:
Although I also love science, I dislike the idea of contrasting it with 
theology or, for lack of a better word, religion, as if the two are 
opposites or mutually exclusive. Sure, they have some distinct differences, 
but I think we could all benefit from looking more at how they're similar, 
rather than different.

Science is great, but not at the expense of everything else.﻿
comments.author: sk8rdman

comments.text:
I would argue that while science deals with the WHAT and the HOW, 
philosophy deals with the WHY. But I can see how, depending on how broad 
your definitions are for philosophy and science, the two could overlap.  
However, I do think that what we learn about the WHAT and the HOW should be 
our basis for drawing conclusions about the WHY. 

Also, you say that science and philosophy are opposites.  Does that mean 
that if you (for lack of a better phrase) put your faith in science, you 
can not prefer a specific philosophy? (And I do not mean only theistic 
philosophies; secular ones should be included as well)
comments.author: Annabelle Barr

comments.text:
Science and religion are complete opposites. But not just religion. Science 
is opposite to any philosophy or ideology. The only people who disagree are 
those who don't know what science even is. In which case I would suggest 
Feynman's lecture on the scientific method: Feynman on Scientific Method.
comments.author: Adam Wojtczak

comments.text: yes
comments.author: sk8rdman

comments.text: Like how religion is great, but not at the expense of science?

comments.author: sagaurora

comments.text:
"Cause I don't think it's bold to question what you're told
If you're told that the world's a thousand years old.
There's nothing here to argue against"
The only part I disagree with in the whole thing. Awesome song :D
(Also, isn't science pretty much built on questioning what you're told? Let 
me paraphrase here:
Everybody in the word: You're stupid, the universe revolves around Earth, 
not the sun!
Galileo: Well I don't think so and I'm going to prove you wrong.")﻿
comments.author: StarlightSong96

comments.text:
Yeah. Hank isn't saying the world is a thousand years old. He is saying 
that if you were told the world was a thousand years old, and you question 
it, you aren't breaking any ground there, since it is proven that the world 
is not thousands of year old, but billions of years old.
comments.author: Zach Sutton

comments.text:
I think the problem here is you aren't understanding what the lyric means, 
he's saying that it isn't bold and weird to question something that you 
clearly see as wrong, it should be second nature.

And the "there's nothing here to argue against" goes with "it's a process 
not an ideology" not the previous lyric c:
comments.author: AHatredOfEs

comments.text:
That's how you learn, by questioning and applying the scientific method. 
Thinking logically and using empirical evidence.

Not "oh because my parents told me" or "because I have a gut feeling" so it 
must be true. Like the song says, science is process not an ideology.
comments.author: FermiFire

comments.text:
I just mean I think that questioning the things people tell you is 
important to learn more about things.
